description: From Middle English filth, from Old English fȳlþu, from Proto-West Germanic *fūliþu, equivalent to foul +‎ -th.

entries.meaning: Dirt; foul matter; that which soils or defiles.
examples: Before we start cooking we need to clean up the filth in this kitchen.

entries.meaning: Smut; that which sullies or defiles the moral character; corruption; pollution.
examples: He spends all his time watching filth on pornographic websites.

entries.meaning: (derogatory, uncountable) A vile or disgusting person.
(US, agriculture, dated) Weeds growing on pasture land.
examples: Grampa remembers when he had to cut filth with a scythe.
We were in the middle of stashing the money when the filth arrived.
